moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bb5 Bb4 5. O-O O-O 6. d3 d6 7. Bg5 Ne7 8. Nh4 c6 9. Bc4 Ne8 10. f4
comment:
A novelty that, at that time, caused a lot of
discussions about its validity. My God! It looks like a bad mistake, a blunder.
The darksquare Bishop looks trapped. Looks? It is! So what? Instead White had
already calculated a combination which needed to sacrifice a piece. And
Schlechter was considered by somebody as a drawish chess player!

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bb5 Bb4 5. O-O O-O 6. d3 d6 7. Bg5 Ne7 8. Nh4 c6 9. Bc4 Ne8 10. f4 Bxc3 11. bxc3 d5 12. Bb3 f6
comment: Here it is! Raise a hand who would have made a different move!

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bb5 Bb4 5. O-O O-O 6. d3 d6 7. Bg5 Ne7 8. Nh4 c6 9. Bc4 Ne8 10. f4 Bxc3 11. bxc3 d5 12. Bb3 f6 13. fxe5 fxg5 14. Rxf8+ Kxf8 15. Qf3+ Kg8 16. Rf1
comment:
In reality, up to now, an identical game
was played a year before in chess club in Berlin and it seems that Emanuel
Lasker reported about it on his chess magazine. We may wonder: did Schlechter
read that article? We do not know.

comment:
This way, instead, the power of the
lightsquare Bishop combined with the action of a reckless King give to White
good winning chances.
